meanings.definition: The bending of light as it passes through different mediums.
meanings.sent1: The refraction of light through water makes objects appear distorted.
meanings.sent2: Scientists study refraction to understand how light behaves in water.
meanings.sent3: The refraction of light through a glass of water can make a straw look bent.
meanings.sent4: Her smile was like the refraction of sunlight on a crystal, bright and beautiful.
meanings.sent5: The refraction of light through a prism creates a rainbow of colors.

meanings.definition: The change in direction of a wave due to a change in its speed.
meanings.sent1: The refraction of the wave caused it to move towards the shore.
meanings.sent2: Surfers often experience refraction when waves change direction suddenly.
meanings.sent3: The refraction of the wave made it look like it was dancing on the water.
meanings.sent4: Her laughter echoed through the room like the refraction of sound waves.
meanings.sent5: The refraction of the wave created a mesmerizing pattern on the surface of the water.

meanings.definition: The process of altering the course of something.
meanings.sent1: The refraction of the river diverted its flow towards the valley.
meanings.sent2: Engineers use refraction to design efficient irrigation systems.
meanings.sent3: The refraction of the ball off the wall surprised everyone in the room.
meanings.sent4: His decision to change careers was a refraction of his desire for new challenges.
meanings.sent5: The refraction of the road ahead forced them to take a different route.
